Blood Death Knight.note: As Deathbringer: during the entire  Dancing Rune Weapon window, or shortly before  Reaper's Mark until you have consumed all  Exterminate procs
Gives you a decent amount of primary stat on a proc. The static budget on it is not great but the trinket's effect makes up for it. It is the best of a bad bunch, and completely passive.
As Deathbringer: during the entire  Dancing Rune Weapon window, or shortly before  Reaper's Mark until you have consumed all  Exterminate procs
Stance - Surekian Decimation - On-use frontal line AoE; passive causes your crits to deal 20% bonus damage to shields.

This is marked as A tier if managed optimally, but it is equivalent to a C-tier trinket if you do not manage it properly. Every time this trinket pulses (1s), it snapshots your current position and verifies if you have moved more than 2 yards. If you have, it subtracts a stack from the primary proc, and adds one to the secondary proc.Your goal on this one is to maintain a 20/10 spread between primary and secondary in order to gain what is slightly more than a regular trinket's worth of value. This is inconvenient as a tank since it requires you to move on demand, which may be problematic in a lot of situations as a number of fights require you to stand still.It is possible to gain a 31st stack of the trinket by letting it fully stack, then rapidly strafing back and forth within a second. This stack permanently remains until either of the buffs reaches 30 or 0 again.

This trinket should be sent on cooldown as much as possible and has very little defensive value in its on-use. The healing from attacking a target is mostly negligible.The maximum HP increase can be particularly juicy on some fights, especially when progressing p3 Queen Ansurek. In Mythic+, you can abuse this by trinket by chain-pulling in order to stay in combat to ramp that max HP buff further, although it is generally not trivial to do so in TWW S1 dungeons thanks to the very large number of forced breaks between packs and sections of dungeons.

This started out as a trinket whose direct effect was 50% better than intended due to it not being affected by the role-specific trinket nerfs, and was changed relatively early on in the season. It is still affected by  Bloodshot and still gains bonus value due to this, but it is now somewhat lackluster instead of being ridiculously better than almost every other trinket.
Second  Dancing Rune Weapon and all other subsequent ones: Hold  Treacherous Transmitter for  Dancing Rune Weapon and use  Treacherous Transmitter one second into  Dancing Rune Weapon

Simulations assume that this trinket will double-hit on every pass of a target, and you should be aiming to achieve this reliably by using this trinket while at max melee range of your target. Failure to do so drops this trinket from B-tier to D-tier.It has no primary budget, meaning that just by equipping it, you will be taking ~2% more physical damage than if you had equipped a "regular" trinket.

Every minute, your next taunt (using either  Dark Command or  Death Grip) gives you a 50% absorb shield for roughly the value of  Swarmlord's Authority, with no downside and a full primary budget. The gotcha, of course, is that you have to taunt a target every minute. If this is part of your cooldown plan for a mechanic that requires frequent taunt swaps, this can cause taunt immunity in the wrong circumstances. In Mythic+, this is significantly less of a problem, but this does not really alleviate how lackluster this trinket is.You can taunt critters (where applicable, if there are any) to pre-shield some pulls.The obvious problem is that any grips will have a chance to trigger this at an unopportune time, putting the trinket on cooldown for the next minute, and while the shield lasts a while (30 seconds), the next auto-attack will consume it.If this trinket fits your cooldown plan for a fight, and there is no other solution to make it work, then it becomes the best of a bad bunch defensively.

This trinket is extremely deceitful as its lack of primary budget means that you automatically take more physical damage (~2% more, value depending on content difficulty, trinket item level and total strength) just by equipping it. The effect itself is also lackluster: every minute, you can shield yourself for ~4M HP. The actual value of the shield depends on haste at the time of the cast since the cast's individual ticks are hasted, allowing you to spawn one more scarab for every 8% of haste you have at time of use.If this trinket fits your cooldown plan for a fight, and there is no other solution to make it work, then it becomes the second best of a bad bunch defensively, but you need to be aware that the effect is not free and that the healing it does is not the full story. Once you account for the effective damage taken increase, you quickly realize that it is an all-else-fails defensive trinket meant to be used to solve a cooldown plan issue, and not a default slot-in.

These two trinkets effectively do almost the same thing: grant you a large mastery on-use effect every 90 seconds. This unfortunately does not really align with anything offensively for Blood, and defensively, the value of a burst of mastery like this one is lackluster. As there is a strict cap on  Blood Shield, such trinkets cause you to just overcap and waste a large amount of their value if used during a period of high damage taken.They are, effectively, as good as they sim; their defensive value is inversely proportional to damage taken and lose value at times when you would think you gain the most value from them.

These two trinkets effectively do almost the same thing: grant you a large mastery on-use effect every 90 seconds. This unfortunately does not really align with anything offensively for Blood, and defensively, the value of a burst of mastery like this one is lackluster. As there is a strict cap on  Blood Shield, such trinkets cause you to just overcap and waste a large amount of their value if used during a period of high damage taken.They are, effectively, as good as they sim; their defensive value is inversely proportional to damage taken and lose value at times when you would think you gain the most value from them.

So much potential wasted due to a nonsensical implementation. The unreliable proc nature of this trinket, and the fact that it is only triggered by direct post-absorb damage taken to a single enemy almost instantly kills it compared to other trinkets that came before it with the same type of post-mitigation flat damage reduction ( Shard of Annhylde's Aegis,  Enduring Dreadplate). And, unfortunately, the damage reduction applied per event on this is very poorly tuned, requiring an absurd amount of low-damage events from the same target to even rival some other trinkets in terms of damage reduction.To give an idea of just how poorly tuned this trinket is,  Reinforced Wax Plating provides the same value at equal item level on every hit from every target independently of conditions, type of damage, proc chance, damage taken prior to impact or activation conditions. If you wanted to use  Ceaseless Swarmgland defensively, you would use  Reinforced Wax Plating instead.

So much potential wasted due to a nonsensical implementation. The unreliable proc nature of this trinket, and the fact that it is only triggered by direct post-absorb damage taken to a single enemy almost instantly kills it compared to other trinkets that came before it with the same type of post-mitigation flat damage reduction ( Shard of Annhylde's Aegis,  Enduring Dreadplate). And, unfortunately, the damage reduction applied per event on this is very poorly tuned, requiring an absurd amount of low-damage events from the same target to even rival some other trinkets in terms of damage reduction.To give an idea of just how poorly tuned this trinket is,  Reinforced Wax Plating provides the same value at equal item level on every hit from every target independently of conditions, type of damage, proc chance, damage taken prior to impact or activation conditions. If you wanted to use  Ceaseless Swarmgland defensively, you would use  Reinforced Wax Plating instead.

Frost Death Knight.note: Both on-use secondary stat trinkets available for Frost this season are nearly identical.  Skarmorak Shard grants small Mastery buffs when you defeat enemies, making this a bit more attractive than  Mark of Khardros in Mythic+. The 90-second cooldown makes this trinket worthwhile for any build. It will line up with your cooldowns whether you play Deathbringer or Rider of the Apocalypse,  Breath of Sindragosa or  Obliteration.
Frost's strongest passive stat trinket this season, with a flavorful damage proc on top. Expect to generally have a few stacks going at a time.

Both on-use secondary stat trinkets available for Frost this season are nearly identical.  Skarmorak Shard grants small Mastery buffs when you defeat enemies, making this a bit more attractive than  Mark of Khardros in Mythic+. The 90-second cooldown makes this trinket worthwhile for any build. It will line up with your cooldowns whether you play Deathbringer or Rider of the Apocalypse,  Breath of Sindragosa or  Obliteration.

A highly unique trinket that outpaces the competition when used properly. When you use it, you will get one of three tasks: stand on a plate, collect an orb, or jump three times. We want to complete the task right before using  Pillar of Frost. The "stand here" and "catch the ball" tasks can be done by running to a spot a few steps forward and right from where you used the trinket. Learning this spot will be key to good timing on lining up the buff with  Pillar of Frost. Consider this more strongly for Mythic+, where you can start the task before pulling a pack. Rider of the Apocalypse builds especially want this trinket, because the Strength buff will empower all the Horsemen. In contrast, the Mastery buff from the other on-use trinkets will do little for the Horsemen.

It isn't easy to gauge this trinket through sims because it revolves around movement. However, it has excellent potential. Our highest secondary stat will be Critical Strike, and we want it almost as much as we want Strength. It will not be a significant penalty if we move a lot and swap the Strength stacks for Critical Strike stacks. Suspending the Strength buff right before using  Breath of Sindragosa will be ideal. However, there may not be time for the buff to reallocate fully if you move a lot. We want to maintain 10-20 stacks of each buff, taking care not to go to 30 in either direction, as stacks above 20 yield fewer stats.

A solid option for both Mythic+ and Raid. The splash range is short, so make sure enemies are gathered before using this trinket. The DoT applied by the trinket will intensify once per tick, so there is no need to force extra damage ticks while the trinket is active.
One of the better placeholders until you can get something better. A solid Strength stick with an okay damage on-use effect.
A better-than-average trinket for Mythic+. Nice passive Strength, and the on-use effect gives us some upfront burst going into a pack.

It is a good Critical Strike stick with an interesting damage on-use effect. After a brief channel, it deals a huge chunk of damage to your target in an attempt to execute it. This trinket may be fun to play with in Mythic+, where you'll have many opportunities to execute targets for more casts. Use this before or after  Pillar of Frost, or you'll lose a GCD.

Unfortunately, the Delve trinkets will fall by the wayside because of their item level disadvantage compared to Mythic+ and Raid trinkets. However, this trinket gets an honorable mention as one to look out for if you play  Breath of Sindragosa. Using it puts you into a cocoon for a couple of seconds; then, you pop out with all stats buffed and a new model. Veterans of the spec may be reminded of a certain trinket from The Eternal Palace...

Unholy Death Knight.note: Another great on-use trinket with a 90-second cooldown. Very similar to  Mark of Khardros, but gives slightly less Mastery on use. As compensation, it also grants you a little Mastery when walking near an enemy's corpse. This secondary effect makes this trinket great for Mythic+ and Delves.

Unholy's strongest on-use trinket option, though it does come with some downsides in that the tasks it gives to complete can be hard to execute at times. This adds an element of risk when using it, and if you can't comfortably adjust to these requirements then consider opting for one of the other on-use alternatives.

Another great on-use trinket with a 90-second cooldown. Very similar to  Mark of Khardros, but gives slightly less Mastery on use. As compensation, it also grants you a little Mastery when walking near an enemy's corpse. This secondary effect makes this trinket great for Mythic+ and Delves.

Another passive trinket, but with a quirk. This trinket performs best when you can stand still for extended periods, but getting some extra Haste when you move is never terrible. Overall, it is slightly better than  Ara-Kara Sacbrood if you manage the stacks well. Ideally for Rider of the Apocalypse, this equates to 15 stacks of both movement and stand still. For San'layn, we want 20 stacks of stand still and 10 stacks of movement.
A passive trinket that can be quite strong if obtained at high item levels through the Great Vault. Generally worse than  Ara-Kara Sacbrood.
A passive trinket that can be quite strong if obtained at high item levels through the Great Vault. Generally worse than  Ara-Kara Sacbrood.
As expected from a damage-effect trinket, it's not the best for Unholy. That said, it still deals good damage, more so in AoE scenarios.
Solid on-use damage trinket with a slow component. Not the best out there for Unholy due to the spec's preferences toward stats, but if it's the best you have then it's a solid option.
Another just-okay trinket that gives a little Strength and does some decent AoE damage. However, as usual, Unholy prefers pure stat trinkets.
On-use damage trinket that does decent damage, all things considered, but doesn't provide the stats that Unholy would prefer.

On-use stat trinket that aligns well with your 90-second cooldown windows. The fact that it grants Versatility does hold this back a bit, compared to a Haste or Mastery trinket with the same same cooldown.

On-use stat trinket that aligns well with your 90-second cooldown windows. The fact that it grants Critical Strike does hold this back a bit, compared to a Haste or Mastery trinket with the same same cooldown.

An Arsenal trinket with a twist - this time it not only deals damage, but also provides some defensive power alongside it. Great for when you want to do decent damage and also need a bit more staying power.
Another passive trinket that deals reasonable damage and also grants some Haste. Unfortunately, the damage component constitutes too much of its power for it to really stand out.

Havoc Demon Hunter.note: An exceptionally powerful on-use cast, with high variability on a single massive hit that relies on landing a critical strike. Very good, but the RNG of critical strikes can be unappealing. BiS for single-target as a double on-use, usually cast after Skardyn's Grace.
Havoc's second strongest on-use trinket, lining up with  Metamorphosis causes this trinket to be BiS for AoE scenarios IF you will not play  Treacherous Transmitter.

Treacherous Transmitter sims incredibly well as one of Havoc Demon Hunter's best trinket options, however actually using this trinket is a bit of a bait and I recommend keeping away if you are not confident in your ability to play around it efficiently. It forces you to do one of three different tasks, which are finding a moving purple orb, standing on a pad that spawns away from you for 3 seconds, or jumping 3 times. All of these take differing amounts of time to perform during your opener, and can be hard to spot.

A powerful passive trinket that can be used if the BiS options are not available. While  Void Reaper's Contract has a 2-set pairing with  Void Reaper's Warp Blade, it does not push it to be significantly more powerful.

Powerful passive stat trinket, with movement being used to gain secondary stats, and remaining stationary for Agility. The on-use is best used when the stats are nearly even, while below 20 stacks of either buff. While this is BiS for mythic+, it is nearly impossible to maintain correct stack counts on Havoc Demon Hunter and is not worth what it sims.
Great passive stat trinket, powerful in all content but not absolute best in slot.
Not as strong for Havoc as other specs due to the base haste, however is a powerful rolling Agility buff that can stack. All around good, but not BiS in single-target or AoE.
Powerful passive trinket. Note, however, that it drops in value if you need to swap targets frequently, which  Burning Wound can cause in Mythic+ scenarios.
Ocarina is a relatively weak trinket on its value to you as the user. However, with the buff applied to all 5 players, it is relatively okay as an option.
Ascension is a relatively powerful trinket for its item level. While it does not hold up once you get to normal raid or higher item level trinkets, it is a good trinket to have access to early on.

Vengeance Demon Hunter.note: This has static Agility, and it deals more damage than any other trinket available aside from  Void Reaper's Contract. When you use it, it grants an hour-long buff that allows your attacks to proc a Nature DoT  Flayedwing Toxin with 4+Haste RPPM.

This trinket has static Haste and a 3+Haste RPPM proc that summons a pet, which deals damage and grants a 50% absorb shield. In addition, it has a 1 minute cooldown on-use which summons 12+Haste scarabs over 3 seconds that each do the same as the random procs. Effectively, it's equivalent to 15+Haste procs per minute, making it our strongest defensive trinket available.

This has static Agility, and it deals more damage than any other trinket available aside from  Void Reaper's Contract. When you use it, it grants an hour-long buff that allows your attacks to proc a Nature DoT  Flayedwing Toxin with 4+Haste RPPM.

This trinket provides static Haste and a 2.5 RPPM effect that grants an Agility buff for an entire minute before hatching, dealing a Nature DoT to an enemy. Each egg proc generates a separate buff, so once it's running, it grants 2.5x as much Agility, on average, as stated on the tooltip.

This is classed as a Tank trinket, so it doesn't have the damage penalty of DPS trinkets. Because of this, it does damage that is nearly on par with full DPS trinkets, while also having defensive benefits! This is exceptionally good in Mythic+ because it has a short 90 second cooldown, while granting a maximum health buff that's great for bosses, while also generating a shield in between pulls that helps buffer us during our weakest point - on pull, before our defensives get rolling. On top of the buff that can stack up to 20 times, this trinket also grants static Agility.
This trinket grants static Agility and a huge Mastery buff for 20 seconds on a 2 minute cooldown. For raw damage, it is exceptionally good in AoE for Fel-Scarred players.

While not particularly powerful at first glance, this is one of the strongest Secondary stat trinkets available, and Vengeance benefits quite a lot from stats. It has static Agility and has 1.55 RPPM on a 20 second buff, so on average it should have ~51.7% uptime.
This trinket grants static Agility and a massive amount of Critical Strike with 1 RPPM for 10 seconds, with roughly 16.7% uptime.
Third Cast: Activates both the prior casts at the same time.

This trinket grants static Critical Strike and an on-use effect with a 2 minute cooldown. It has a 1 second cast time, during which you are unable to dodge or parry, but deals a massive amount of damage over 2 sec to a priority target, and it deals scaling increased damage to enemies with missing health. In addition, if the enemy dies during the debuff, the cooldown is cut in half to 1 minute, making it a fantastic option in multi-target fights. However, by default it's not as strong as other trinkets that aren't reliant on the cooldown reduction.

This trinket is a purely defensive option in Mythic+, with a 15% attack speed reduction for 15 seconds on an extremely short 1 minute cooldown, while also granting a small shield. The shield isn't particularly good, but 25% uptime on the largest source of damage intake that is available for every pull is fantastic. Unfortunately, coming from Delves, it has a maximum item level of 626.

Despite granting static Versatility, this trinket grants a 20 sec Dodge buff once per minute, which can be a large amount of damage reduction over the course of a Mythic+ dungeon due to the melees avoided. It has roughly 33% uptime.

This trinket has no baseline stats. Instead, you generate stacks of either Agility or your highest Secondary stat based on whether you are standing still or moving, at a rate of 1 per second. When you activate the on-use, it will freeze the stack counts at their current amounts for 20 seconds once every 2 minutes. This is pretty annoying to use, so despite the potentially large gain, it loses some value.

This is technically a DPS trinket, so it suffers from the 33% damage penalty to non-Tanks, and since it comes from Delves, its maximum item level is only 626. Despite this, because the damage based on movement speed increase portion applies to all increases, including those from our talents, this trinket is actually still decent.

This trinket has static Agility and a 6+Haste RPPM proc which occurs on damage taken, putting a 6 second DoT on enemies that also reduces their damage dealt to you by a flat amount for 6 seconds. It's not bad overall, but not great.
Grants static Agility and an on-use effect with 1 minute cooldown that deals uncapped AoE damage. It's pretty solid, but has a maximum item level of 626.

Grants static Versatility and a 1 RPPM proc of a large Agility buff, as well as boosting the effect of healing potions. Not great, but a decent crafted option if you have spare sparks and no good trinkets. It has a maximum item level of 636.
Jump 3 times.

This trinket has static Agility and whenever you taunt, it grants a shield that reduces damage you take by 50%, up to a cap with a 1 minute ICD. Unfortunately, the size of the shield is extremely low despite being on-demand, and incentivizes taunting for purposes other than regaining aggro.

This trinket has no stats, but instead has an on-use effect with a 2 minute cooldown that deals damage to enemies in an arc. This damage is reduced for each enemy hit. In addition, it adds a small passive proc on auto-attacks which can reduce the on-use cooldown by 5 seconds and adds a small amount of Fire damage to your next melee. It's not great.

This trinket has static Agility and a 1.66 RPPM proc on dealing damage, which spawns an orb flying to your current target, dealing split AoE damage. Intercepting the orb grants Mastery for 15 seconds instead. Due to the 33% non-DPS spec penalty, we always want to grab the orb, but it's not great for damage due to being Mastery.

This trinket grants static Agility and when used, grants a 15 minute buff on you that has a 1 RPPM proc to grant allies a selected Secondary stat for 15 seconds. It's pretty bad, despite being a group support item.

Balance Druid.note: A minigame trinket. This can be obnoxious, depending on what buff you get. Double on-use with this and  Spymaster's Web is quite strong. Download this weakaura to help play with this trinket to maximum effectiveness: https://wago.io/jX4s-GYvb

A minigame trinket. This can be obnoxious, depending on what buff you get. Double on-use with this and  Spymaster's Web is quite strong. Download this weakaura to help play with this trinket to maximum effectiveness: https://wago.io/jX4s-GYvb

A unique trinket that grants Intellect once eggs are spawned. They deal damage once they hatch, though note that the actual hatching process takes some time to occur. This trinket's stat budge is very high for both AoE and single-target.
Good trinket that grants a sizable amount of Intellect via its proc. Pretty solid for both AOE and single-target. Can be farmed from the Grim Batol dungeon.
This trinket has a powerful amount of baseline Intellect with a random Secondary stat proc effect. Can also be farmed outside of raid, as it comes from The Dawnbreaker dungeon.
This is a strong, passive Secondary stat trinket. Can be farmed from the Mists of Tirna Scithe dungeon.
This trinket grants both Primary and Secondary stats based on movement. It can also be  "used" to suspend your current buffs. It's slightly worse than some other options, but not horrible.

Feral Druid.note: The best stat on-use trinket available. It lines up with our cooldowns and provides a huge chunk of a powerful stat.

The best passive stat trinket for AoE, where other options fall behind. While you'll still want a primary on-use trinket, a secondary trinket that provides a stat boost rather than direct damage becomes a lot more attractive, and it helps that this is also very competitive on single-target. This is also best option for a second trinket on Mythic+.
Similar to Sacbrood, this is one of the best Secondary stat trinkets available.
While not quite as competitive as the Spyglass or Ara-Kara Sacbrood, this is another fine alternative.

The best second trinket option of raids. It's an on-use, but since it deals damage there's no harm in desyncing it from your cooldowns. Does massive damage on use, and since many other specs aren't quite as happy with this trinket as Feral is, it should be fairly easy to obtain due to a lack of competition.

The second best stat on-use trinket available, and the best one from the raid. It doesn't line up with your cooldowns as perfectly as other options, so you'll usually need to hold it for 30 seconds to sync it. The minigames it requires can be a little annoying to fully take advantage of, but it's still a strong option.

A more passive alternative to Mad Queens Mandate, but still a competitive option. There may be high competition for this trinket as Monks, Demon Hunters, and Rogues have a set bonus combination with it.
A strong trinket but one that is limited in item level to Heroic levels only. At comparable item levels, its one of the best secondary trinket options available.
A strong trinket but one that is limited in item level to Heroic levels only. At comparable item levels, its one of the best secondary trinket options available.
A strong trinket but one that is limited in item level to Heroic levels only. At comparable item levels, its one of the better secondary trinket options available.
A strong trinket but one that is limited in item level to Heroic levels only. At comparable item levels, its one of the best secondary trinket options available.
Much stronger on AoE than on single-target.
This trinket is available from PvP and is a very competitive alternative to other on-use trinkets if they haven't dropped yet.

Guardian Druid.note: Can be very powerful if you manage to kill targets with it, which will reduce the on-use cooldown.
Deals decent damage and provides a stacking health effect across the entire fight. This is great on long fights and/or progression.
A nice passive trinket that grants our Primary stat and deals some minor damage.
Can grant impressive amounts of Critical Strike.
Great Haste passive with a fairly strong defensive healing bonus.
Provides a large amount of mastery that we can line up well with  Incarnation: Guardian of Ursoc/ Rage of the Sleeper or  Lunar Beam.
Provides a chunk of our Primary stat with a small on-use damage effect, making this one of the better DPS trinkets from Mythic+.
Decent passive trinket with a Mastery proc.
This provides a mediocre on-use effect on a short cooldown.
This trinket is decent on encounters where you don't have to move too often.

Grants a large amount of our Primary stat for a short period, but requires  you to execute some sort of puzzle task such as jumping 3 times or chasing an orb. Can be detrimental, depending on when you use it.

Restoration Druid.note: Spymaster's Web is the perfect compliment to our frequent ramps. It puts our power where we need it the most. You'll use it either every minute or every two minutes, depending on what is more useful to the fight. The downside is you do need to keep a  Moonfire active on the boss.  Grove Guardians will take care of some of them, but you'll need to cast the rest. If you aren't good with  Moonfire uptime, then this trinket isn't very good. It's also quite a bit worse in Mythic+.
Another solid Haste stat stick with a decent uptime. It ends up being a slightly less consistent version of  Gale of Shadows.
Another solid Haste stat stick with a decent uptime. It ends up being a slightly less consistent version of  Gale of Shadows.

This is a weird DPS trinket that actually ends up being a full budget stat stick with a small DPS bonus. You don't need to play around it, though casting an occasional DPS spell will be of increased value.
Another high uptime stat stick. It's a bit worse than the S-tier trinkets but it's still very usable.

This is a slightly awkward on-use healing trinket, which is likely to be fairly good in lower tier content and worse by the time you get to Mythic. It also gives you a little free damage via the allies you heal.
This isn't available at maximum item level, which holds it back from being a top tier trinket. It's otherwise a very consistent, decent early trinket to pick up.
An on-use Haste trinket to pair with  Incarnation: Tree of Life. Not available at maximum item level.
This isn't a top tier raid trinket, but a short cooldown shield can be fairly useful in Mythic+ - even if this one is quite a bit smaller than some we've seen in the past.

A bizarre proc trinket that will give various buffs to your allies including an Intellect proc, Secondary procs, Tertiary procs, and more. The Primary stat buff is actually very strong, but you'll get it too inconsistently.
This will mostly play as a flat healing trinket, since you're likely to get the intellect buff when you need it the least (nobody injured). As a result it's of lower value.

Devastation Evoker.note: Our best trinket by far, with a flexible on-use effect that allows it to function as a stat stick and a powerful steroid. Generally, we stack this buff until damage increase windows or execute phases. Dying removes your stacks, so beware!
Strong passive damage proc trinket with a lackluster on-use effect. Be careful using this if you plan to use another trinket before the 20 second trinket cooldown finishes. Moves to B tier in AoE.
Damage trinket that hits harder in execute range. Its cooldown is halved if target is killed. Moves to B tier in AoE, unless you can consistently get resets on the kill effect.
Very strong passive trinket that has a chance to proc damage and return Intellect.
Interesting trinket that either gives you Intellect when standing still, or your highest Secondary stat when moving. Using the trinket will pause the stacks at their current amount.
Decent passive stat increase. It procs from DoT effects.
Strong passive trinket. The stats this trinket provides can be customized to your character's needs. See item for more information.
Passive Secondary stat increase to a random stat.
This trinket summons candle pets that attack your target. It deals a surprising amount of damage.

On-use trinket that gives you instructions to complete certain tasks, and then provides Intellect upon their completion. This trinket is a bit of a hassle to work around, but you can stagger the buff to make it last longer.
Chance to cause a waterspout that is split between targets, but increases in damage in AoE. This trinket can miss if targets are moving.
Chance to cause a small explosion that is split between targets, but increases in damage for each enemy struck (up to 5 enemies).
Damage proc that sends out an orb to deals damage. Catching this orb yourself will instead grant you Mastery. Better in AoE, but still outclassed by other trinkets.
Moves to A-tier in AoE if it has a higher item level. Decent on-use trinket that provides Haste and movement speed, but is held back by its low item level.
Cool on-use trinket that changes your model and gives you a strong buff. This trinket's on-use effect does have a cast time. Unfortunately, it is held back by its lower item level.
On-use trinket that deals damage and provides Secondary stats to you and your allies.

Preservation Evoker.note: Changeling is a classic, but powerful stat stick. The Secondary stat it procs will change based on the food you eat. We will be looking for the Mastery proc.
Haste is not our preferred Secondary, but this is still a very good trinket since you will maintain 100% uptime and it's slightly overbudget.

This is a powerful trinket that we'll combine with  Stasis to improve our burst healing. It's a little less powerful on us than some other Healers, but is still strong enough to belong in S tier. Note that it does require you keep  Fire Breath active.
A fairly generic stat stick with high uptime that rotates through random Secondaries.
This is a full budget stat stick with a small DPS bonus attached. Sadly, it's also a Haste trinket, so it's just decent for us.
It's easy to contribute enough healing to quickly proc the burst here, so you'll use this during any dangerous damage.
This trinket isn't available at maximum item level, which keeps it from S-tier. That said, it can be a decent early pickup.
The shield this trinket generates isn't very big, and the trinket itself isn't available at maximum level. This means you'll only use it if you desperately need an on-use shield trinket in Mythic+.
Gives various buffs to your allies, including an Intellect proc, Secondary stat procs, Tertiary stat procs, and more. It's too inconsistent to be great.
We don't have anything good to combine with a 2 minute on-use trinket.
This trinket has an awkward design because the Intellect proc is more powerful, but you'll only get it when nobody is injured.
Does not have intellect on it.

Augmentation Evoker.note: One of the strongest trinkets available to casters for progression content. Passive Mastery benefits Augmentation's stat priority, but the secondary effect is where this trinket shines. While it takes some time to ramp up in value, and is less effective immediately on pull or in short encounters, this trinket is an absolute powerhouse for difficult progression encounters. Use this trinket during your  Breath of Eons cooldown window every 4 minutes for a massive burst window.

Critical Strike is an excellent Secondary stat for Augmentation Evoker, and the direct damage dealt by this trinket is quite substantial, particularly for an Augmentation Evoker with limited single-target burst potential. Additionally, this trinket also becomes more effective against enemies with lower health.
Passive Haste and an effect that essentially provides passive Intellect as well as direct damage. This trinket specifically deals Nature damage, which can be noteworthy for certain item interactions.

This trinket's on-use effect deals direct damage and also provides 5 allies with Versatility. While these sorts of support effects are not always great, this trinket's total output is actually quite good. It is worth considering on Augmentation, even though you will be using this as a two-minute trinket combined with your  Breath of Eons. Do note that the Versatility provided to allies will not appear as part of your damage contribution in logs or meters, as you might expect.

This trinket is essentially an overbudget Intellect + Mastery stat stick with a downside that procs infrequently. Overall this trinket is quite good for Augmentation. The only major caveat is that, as usual, Delve trinkets can only be obtained at Hero track via the Great Vault, and cannot reach Myth track like items from Raid or Mythic+. This is still a solid trinket overall, even at lower item levels.

Essentially an Intellect stat stick that becomes more powerful over the course of an encounter. This trinket is quite decent when allowed to ramp up, notably in progression raid encounters, but is significantly less effective in dungeon content like Mythic+ or Delves.

A somewhat interesting take on the typical stat stick. You will begin with 30 stacks of Intellect out of combat, and are generally encouraged to maintain a balance of both stacks to maximize overall value.  While I'm not generally keen on effects which restrict mobility on Evoker, minimizing movement should allow you to maintain stacks of Intellect, particularly in certain encounters.

A more traditional stat stick design from this Shadowlands favourite, with Augmentation Evokers appreciating the passive Intellect. Eat for Mastery or Critical Strike to change the Secondary stat proc based on your personal stat distribution.
Passive Intellect coupled with a direct damage proc. This is a simple and effective Augmentation trinket, and the slight damage scaling with targets helps its value in AoE.

A strong 2 minute cooldown stat amplification trinket that aligns well with the  Breath of Eons burst window, and is available immediately at the start of the fight. As a Delve trinket, it cannot be obtained at Myth track item level.

Once this trinket's stacks are online it is quite effective, but the ramp time does make the effect somewhat less valuable on pull and in dungeon settings like Mythic+ and Delves. Augmentation also generally takes a bit longer than other specs to cast its first periodic effect, which further delays the value gained.
A typical Intellect stat stick with a random Secondary stat proc. On average this trinket produces decent results, but has inherent variability in that it can hit less desirable Secondary stats.

Passive Intellect and an effect that provides either direct damage or Mastery checks all the boxes for Augmentation. The orb effect spawns behind you and quickly moves towards the enemy in such a way that can be difficult to anticipate, especially in combat.

Passive Intellect and an effect that seems, at first glance, to be an interesting support effect for Augmentation Evoker. In practice the average result is rather lackluster, making the support aspect of this trinket fairly weak.
The on-use Intellect of this trinket is reasonable, but the 90 sec cooldown leaves budget on the table for a 2 minute spec like Augmentation. The tasks can also be a bit distracting while in combat.
This trinket simply provides limited upside, numerically, when compared with other available alternatives.

While technically usable as an Intellect stat stick, the random nature of the secondary effect leaves too much to be desired to consider using this over available alternatives. Additionally, as a Delve trinket this is not available at the highest item level unlike alternatives from Raid or Mythic+.

An interesting trinket based on stacking different spell schools to maximize its effects. Cannot be crafted above item level 577, and is overtaken by the  Darkmoon Sigil: Vivacity  embellishment instead.

Marksmanship Hunter.note: Our outright BiS for all things single-target, for any Hero Talent.
The best all-rounder Trinket for Dark Ranger.
The best all-rounder Trinket for Sentinel. Can be macro'd to  Trueshot.
Technically a Tank/Melee Trinket, but its on-use has no range limitation and does excellent single-target damage.
Useful for sustained fights, but not great for stop-start situations like Mythic+, since the Trinket stacks a debuff on the target that obviously gets reset if that target dies.
A decent alternative to Skardyn's Grace, but clearly a step worse.

Survival Hunter.note: This can be a reasonable alternative to  Skardyn's Grace in a pinch, however it is nowhere near as powerful even at 626, which is the maximum itemlevel of  Quickwick Candlestick.
This is a bit of an awkward trinket, but on paper it provides a large amount of stats, which scales well into Single Target and AoE alike.

Very similar to  Empowering Crystal of Anub'ikkaj, but has a downside attached to where in order to stack up the crit buff you need to be attacking the target it procced from. This can somewhat lower its expected stat returns in an environment where it can proc on a very fast dying mob you didn't neccesarily want it to proc onto. With that said, it still provides a great amount of critical strike.
Performs very well for Single Target damage, but falls behind drastically for AoE. We cannot make use of the set effect since we cannot utilise the fist weapon that requires it.

Performs very well for both ST and AoE alike, making it an incredibly versatile trinket! it does not currently compare that well against some of the pre-season offerings, but those are unavailable at higher itemlevels once season 1 begins.

Very similar to  Empowering Crystal of Anub'ikkaj, but has a downside attached to where in order to stack up the crit buff you need to be attacking the target it procced from. This can somewhat lower its expected stat returns in an environment where it can proc on a very fast dying mob you didn't neccesarily want it to proc onto. With that said, it still provides a great amount of critical strike.

Very powerful, passive trinket. It does reduce your secondary stats randomly, which can impact you in important damage phases, but most of the time it reduces an unimportant stat (versatility or critical strike). However, this trinket is limited in power due to only being obtainable at a high ilevel through the great vault or specifically Delve maps.
This can be a reasonable alternative to  Skardyn's Grace in a pinch, however it is nowhere near as powerful even at 626, which is the maximum itemlevel of  Quickwick Candlestick.
This trinket has incredibly random but fun effects, although they aren't incredibly potent they do offer some bonus niche effects such as avoidance and run speed.
Deals very sustained single target damage, competing even with some of the S-tier options. However, it struggles to deal AoE damage effectively, dropping its overall rating down a lot.
Incredibly awkard, but very powerful in theory. A lot of the value here comes from the ability to intercept the orb. If you struggle with this the true value is likely closer to C tier.

A fairly versatile and strong trinket, but the tasks can be a little tedious or restrictive, requiring you to chase an orb, jump a few times, or to stand in a purple zone. These tasks are especially restrictive in Mythic+, where the trinket performs best.
Can deal a respectable amount of burst damage, but its use effect awkwardly conflicts with that of other on-use trinkets.

Another delve trinket, aiming more at potentionally buffing allies. However, unlike  Mistcaller Ocarina it appears to split the buff with your ally rather than getting the full effect. This means you might not want to share the buff at all if you happen to have your cooldowns active! As with all Delve trinkets, the maximum itemlevel is limited at 626.
The lack of any primary or secondary stat hurts this trinket in particular. The random procced damage it deals is nowhere near worth enough to give up the raw stats.

Another delve trinket, aiming more at potentionally buffing allies. However, unlike  Mistcaller Ocarina it appears to split the buff with your ally rather than getting the full effect. This means you might not want to share the buff at all if you happen to have your cooldowns active! As with all Delve trinkets, the maximum itemlevel is limited at 626.

Possibly interesting. it is currently unclear how much the damage effect scales with speed effects. However, given how far down its performance currently is i doubt that even  Aspect of the Cheetah could make up for it.

Arcane Mage.note: This trinket is incredibly powerful due to how flexible it is, not using it at all is also not even that bad due to the stacking buff. Overall we'll aim to collect stacks on this until execute phases, then use our cooldowns with it for huge damage. If the fight is long enough, try to stagger using it such that you get full stacks in execute, but also don't let stacks go to waste. Make sure you save your potion and other cooldowns to use with this in execute!
Blizzard was quick to fix this trinket so we could not use it with Spymaster's, however it is still strong, aim to use it 6-7s before  Evocation, then activate the buff when you're ready to burst!
Our strongest passive trinket from a dungeon, it sounds interesting but its the definition of a trinket you don't think about.

A great secondary option to Spymasters, the cooldown of this trinket is what makes it decent, you can get 2/3 of your bursts windows by staggering its usage or just using it off cooldown, either works!.
The limited ilvl here does not matter, this trinket is very strong on its own despite the ilevel restriction on delve loot.
A very strong passive trinket, not as good as other options but a bit more customizable to your character's needs.
Simple trinket, try to use it if you have to move a ton so that you maintain the primary stat buff - that said, its not a real issue if you dont.
A bit better in AOE than in single target, but kind of obnoxious when mobs are moving and it procs.
Proc damage that goes boom, its not as terrible as it was in Shadowlands!
A solid use trinket, just held back by lower being ilevel.
A stronger passive trinket from delves, don't worry about the stats you lose, it balances out in the long run.
A boring proc trinket in disguise - make sure you don't use it if you're going to use another trinket within 20s for your cooldowns.
A stronger passive trinket from delves, it just does some damage, nothing crazy.
Another good passive trinket from delves, notice a trend here?
Kind of a neat trinket idea but not super great in execution.

A very strong trinket pound for pound, but being available at a limited ilvl holds it back a ton, the cast time is also a double edged sword, it sucks to use in combat but can also be used before combat so your mileage might vary quite a bit with this trinket.

Fire Mage.note: By far our best trinket. Flexible on-use trinket that functions as a stat stick and a powerful steroid. Generally, we stack this buff until damage increases or execute phases. Dying removes your stacks, so beware!
Very strong passive trinket. Chance to proc damage and return intellect.
On-use trinket that gives you instructions that provide intellect on completion. This trinket is a bit of a hassle, but you can stagger the buff to make it last longer.
Decent passive stat increase. Procs from damage-over-time effects.
Interesting trinket that either gives you intellect when standing still, or your highest secondary stat when moving. Using the trinket will pause the stacks.

This trinket summons candle pets that attack your target. It does a surprising amount of damage.  The AI on the minions it spawns is kind of bad so it likely will underperform in AoE. Only really recommended for Single Target.
Strong passive trinket. The stats this trinket provides can be customizable to your character's needs. See item for more information.
Passive secondary stat increase to a random stat.
Chance to cause a waterspout that is split between targets, but increases in damage in AOE. This trinket can miss if targets are moving.
Decent on-use trinket that provides Haste and movement speed, but held back by its low itemlevel.
Chance to cause a small explosion that is split between targets, but increases in damage up to 5 targets.
Damage proc that sends out an orb that deals damage. Catching this orb gives you Mastery instead. Better in AoE, but still outclassed by other trinkets.
Passive damage proc trinket with a lackluster on-use effect. Be careful using this if you plan to use another trinket before the 20 second trinket cooldown finishes.
Cool on-use trinket that changes your model and gives you a strong buff. This trinket requires casting. This trinket is held back by its lower itemlevel.
On use trinket that deals damage and provides secondary stats to you and your allies.

Frost Mage.note: This is a good active trinket that can be paired with  Icy Veins. Note that if you have a  Spymaster's Web, you can still use this trinket to decent effect because you will not be using  Spymaster's Web very often.
This is the best passive stat trinket for Frost Mages in The War Within Season 1.
A very strong trinket that drops in delves. Because the summoned pet can be a melee attacker, this trinket is better if you stay close to your target.

This trinket is unusual in that you can choose which stats it provides. Generally, you will probably want the Haste or Mastery version, but it's best to simulate your character to see which is the best for you.
This is another good passive stat trinket option. Spellslinger can proc this with  Embedded Frost Splinter while Frostfire can proc this with the damage over time effect applied by  Frostfire Bolt.
This is a pretty boring passive damage trinket, but it performs well.

This is a complicated trinket, but generally you can just think of it as a passive stat boost. Because stacks above 20 grant a reduced effect, you should try to keep both types of stacks below 20 and use the active to keep it balanced there.

This is a good active trinket that can be paired with  Icy Veins. Note that if you have a  Spymaster's Web, you can still use this trinket to decent effect because you will not be using  Spymaster's Web very often.
While not available at maximum item level, this is a solid active trinket.
This is a decent passive trinket that does some extra damage in AoE, but it is problematic against moving targets because it can miss.
This is a passable passive stat trinket.

Brewmaster Monk.note: While it does not feature Agility, Critical Strike is the best secondary you could hope for as a Brewmaster on a trinket like this. Although its damage is noteworthy enough to be your best choice for lower target counts, your success with this trinket will be additionally determined by whether or not you can take advantage of its bonus effects of extra damage on lower-health targets and cooldown reduction for defeating an enemy with it.Beyond that, its heal effect is insignificant, and it should also be noted that you cannot dodge attacks while channeling its 1-second cast time (though you can move during it).

This trinket's damage is acceptable on its own (despite the 33% damage penalty for being a dps trinket), but when paired with the  Void Reaper's Warp Blade, its full potential is unlocked and brings it to new heights. Consider this among your best options for single-target, and a solid choice for AoE.

Despite being a tank trinket, the damage output from this item is exceptionally competitive with the strongest options, and that's before considering that it also has additional defensive benefits! Plus, the additional maximum health from overhealing with this trinket ( Nerubian Fortitude) acts as a small buff to your  Touch of Death damage!Seek this out as a potent on-use choice with some hybrid bonuses that likely isn't being claimed by a dps player.

Despite having static Haste, the 2.5ppm effect of this trinket grants its Agility buff for an entire minute before the egg hatches and applies its Nature DoT to an enemy. This all comes together for a surprisingly effective trinket.

Due to being penalized on tank specializations for being a dps trinket, this item is only a decent choice rather than one of the absolute best. Remember to re-apply its effect when the buff expires or you have died!

While this trinket gives no stats on its own, you will passively generate either Agility or your highest secondary stat based on whether you are standing still or moving. This results in building or losing one stack of each buff per second, with the option to freeze the stack counts at their current amounts once every 2-minutes. Overall, you will need to maintain large amounts of the Agility stack count in particular for this trinket to excel, so don't fidget too much! When properly utilized, this trinket represents one of your strongest choices in AoE.

This trinket may have a reduced maximum item level due its source being Delves, but its defensive effect remains one of the most potent available for dungeons due to its attack speed reduction on enemies affected by the on-use. Be aware that it will not be as effective on higher-level enemies such as bosses or minibosses, however!

This trinket represents the definition of "average", offering a 20 second buff to a random secondary stat roughly 1.55 times per minute. It exists in the background and does nothing special, but is at least reliably doing something.

The on-use nature of this trinket's (massive) Mastery buff results in it being an acceptable choice for both damage and defense. It being perhaps the second-best defensive trinket of the season says a lot about your available options.

The static Haste present on this trinket immediately hinders its total defensive potential, just as the damage from the scarabs being Physical greatly hinders its offensive power (due to being reduced by enemy Armor). However, the short 1-minute cooldown on its on-use effect does translate to a reliable source of potent mitigation when you are in need of it.As for its Haste-based bonus, you will send approximately one additional scarab per 10% of Haste, including Haste from temporary bonuses like  Veteran's Eye or  Bloodlust.

Mistweaver Monk.note: With this trinket set to Haste, it's one of the best options we could hope for in raids. Similar to  Gale of Shadows, this is just a great passive trinket that increases our Intellect and Haste.
With this trinket set to Haste, it's one of the best options we could hope for in raids. Similar to  Gale of Shadows, this is just a great passive trinket that increases our Intellect and Haste.

With a baseline amount of Haste (do you see the pattern starting to form?), the passive effect provides a surprisingly good amount of Intellect, making it just a hair stronger than [item=178708 bonus=[=gv-sl-dun:6917]] and its effect. The damage that it does is just a nice extra perk this trinket brings, but it isn't the reason it ranks as high as it does.

This is just a nice stat stick! While it can give us Haste, Critical Strike, or Versatility, it's lowered a few positions because of the possibility of it giving us Mastery. In Mythic+ however, its ranking is much more impressive because of this! Not much else to say about it though, the base amount of Intellect is great, and the secondary stat buff lasts long enough to make great use of it.

With a recent change to what triggers this trinket, it's now one of our best trinkets, provided we use a damaging ability every 6 seconds. This makes sure that the stacks of the buff continually grow. Because we don't have any periodic damaging spells, we need to make sure we cast  Tiger Palm,  Blackout Kick, or  Rising Sun Kick every 6 seconds while in combat. Pair the activated effect with any of our cooldowns to make your healing during them even more effective!

When you use this trinket, it reduces your healing by 20% until you meet its cap, which happens quickly, and then it turns that amplifies that stored healing to heal several allies. Thankfully, there's an additional effect if it overheals its targets, allowing them to deal some extra damage to their target. This trinket is definitely one that you need to time its use very well with upcoming mechanics, but at least there's still some value if you get the timing a little off, or it decides to heal someone who doesn't need the healing. Because you can guarantee the five allies it'll hea lin Mythic+, this is definitely something worth keeping if you haven't had much luck getting better trinkets.

This trinket allows you to decide how much Intellect or Haste it gives you, with Intellect's stacks climbing while you stay still and diminishing while moving, while Haste works vice versa. There's a cooldown that allows you to keep your current buff numbers frozen for 20 seconds, but outside of this, you want to try and maintain 20 stacks of Intellect and 10 stacks of Haste. This trinket requires a fair bit of work to optimize, and there are other trinkets that do what it does without needing to track the stacks of two buffs.

Windwalker Monk.note: The best trinket that doesn't come from Raid, since it escaped the first round of trinket tuning. Mastery isn't as plentiful currently as in the past, so getting a big chunk of it is *chef's kiss*.

This trinket gives huge Haste and even bigger Agility. All you have to do is successfully complete a task that can range from the easy to the frustrating. If you can stand to play with that then this trinket is incredibly strong and is a requirement if you want to play Conduit of the Celestials for big burst every 90 seconds.
A very strong trinket that only gets stronger if you already have the weapon that goes with it, which you should be aiming to get. It is the strongest trinket we can get with an "Equip" effect.
The slight nerf it recieved moves it down to A from S, but it is still the 2nd best trinket with an "Equip" effect.
This trinket does a HUGE amount of damage with the on-use ability. If you can somehow get it to kill the targets and use it 2x as often, its an easy S-tier trinket.

Holy Paladin.note: This trinket procs from HoTs or DoTs only. As such it is great for Herald. For Lightsmith it only procs of  Consecration so you will need to keep it down, which isn't a problem in Dungeons but might be a little annoying in Raid.
A simple proc trinket that will always work well. Procs stat based on the latest secondary food buff you consumed.

A decent stat stick. You will always have 30 stacks combined active, moving causes you to lose main stat but gain secondary. The optimal ratio is 20 intellect stacks and 10 secondary, but it is generally not something you should play around. Just keep in mind to not move around too much.

The on-use effect should be used with your Wings. To gain the optimal effect of this trinket, you need to cast an offensive spell every 6 seconds. If you do not come close to proccing it on that 6 second cooldown, it loses a ton of value. In dungeons this is not a problem as you will be having  Consecration down permanently. In raids, it loses a lot of value as you will not be proccing it every 6 seconds consistently, unless you keep  Consecration down, which isn't worth it.
A simple on use trinket that heals 5 players after a while of you "filling it up", which you do by simply continuing to heal normally.
Should simply be used with  Avenging Wrath every 2 minutes.

You will be assigned one of three tasks when using this trinket. You will either have to jump 3 times, run over a small orb on the ground, or stand in a portal on the ground. Accomplishing the task grants you a decent bit of intellect for 15 seconds.
When used, deals damage to your target and causes the 5 next people to attack that target to be healed and gain a small amount of Vers.
This trinket can be used to shield 1 player. Trinkets like this are historically pretty bad for raiding, but are useful in high Mythic+ where they can help provide an extra external.

This trinket is a little strange. You would always prefer to have the intellect, but when you need it the most it will consume the stacks to shoot out a low heal and reduce the intellect it gives which makes this trinket not super good.

Protection Paladin.note: This is the best trinket available right now. It has passive haste and a solid proc rate of constant passive damage and strength. You'll have ~1-3 stacks of the strength buff at any given time.

This is an absorption trinket with an on-use that scales with Haste. The on-use has a slight delay so with good planning, you will get a nice absorb shield that will give some damage smoothing on top of some smoothing from passive absorbs.
A mastery on-use that is much better in M+ or AoE where you're killing mobs for the secondary part. In single target this is worse than the other Mastery on-use option.
This is a large amount of passive dodge that will proc on cooldown, especially in Mythic+.
Another on-use Mastery option that is better for single-target situations.
This is an easy to get trinket that you can look into if you have some bad luck with dungeon or raid drops.
This gives stacking strength just for attack. You can have ~1-5 stacks of bonus strength and it has an on-use of moderate shadow damage.

This trinket will ask you to jump in place or run on top of a portal. It can be very awkward but doing it gives a lot of strength. This trinket does have use cases in raid situations where you have little movement.

This is a weak trinket that gives you an absorb when you taunt. This trinket doesn't work in raid at all because timings usually allow for cooldowns to be cycled quickly so the shield is not really needed. In M+, you could have potentially used it to help fill defensive gaps but the shield strength is not enough. It's barely a single melee swing as key levels get higher.

Retribution Paladin.note: On use Mastery trinket. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
On use Mastery trinket. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive stat trinket with a small DoT component. No special usage required.

Stacks Strength or a secondary stat depending on whether you're standing still or moving. If possible, you want to maintain 20 stacks of the secondary stat buff and 10 of Strength. A strong trinket if you play around it, but requires significant attention for it to be competitive.
On use damage. Use on cooldown unless you won't get another cast during the encounter; in that case you should delay as its damage is increased against lower health targets.

On use Strength buff. It requires you to make follow directions, making specific movements to apply the buff. Use early enough that you'll have the buff active before  Wake of Ashes. Another trinket that is strong, but requires significant attention in order to properly use it and can have its use severely constrained by the mechanics of an encounter.
Passive statstick. No special usage required.
On use damage. Use on cooldown.
On use damage. Use near the end of combat or against add spawns; keep the Strength stacks otherwise.
On use damage. Use on cooldown. Try to stay close enough to the target so that it won't break early.
Passive damage proc. No special usage required.
On use Haste buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive Strength proc. No special usage required.

Discipline Priest.note: Provides a stacking intellect buff that you can consume. Your goal is to consume this around every 1.5mins with  Evangelisms cooldown for your ramps in a raid.
Very strong intellect gain, currently very highly tuned.
Excellent stat trinket, uses food buffs to change stat buff. Discipline prefers to set to haste.
Excellent stat stick, even with a random stat buff
On-use that redirects part of your healing to feed the coagulum. When it is fully fed it detonates for a burst of healing.
We believe this is a delve drop that is higher tuned than most.
Mid  passive trinket, providing healing and stats.
Intellect trinket with a solid shield effect. Random but effective!
Mythic0 trinket. Solid option but likely to get replaced later.

Holy Priest.note: Excellent stat trinket, uses food buffs to change stat buff. Holy prefers crit or mastery.
On-use that redirects part of your healing to feed the coagulum. When it is fully fed it detonates for a burst of healing.
Excellent stat stick, even with a random stat buff
Very strong intellect gain, currently very highly tuned.
Strong mastery and primary stat buff
Intellect trinket with a solid shield effect. Random but effective!
We believe this is a delve drop that is higher tuned than most.
Delve drop with a haste increase.
Mid passive trinket, providing healing and stats.
Mythic0 trinket. Solid option but likely to get replaced later.

Shadow Priest.note: Strong trinket with main stat stacking effect and an on-use that accrues value passively, this is excellent for using alongside major cooldowns and at difficult parts of a boss or dungeon.

Unique trinket that grants intellect once eggs are spawned, when they hatch, damage is also dealt. This trinket is finnicky to use and requires a long time to get full value, but can be interesting in some situations.

Unbound Changeling can proc a random secondary stat, but also has a chance to "change" into a version that grants ALL secondary stats, this chance can occur the first time you eat food in-game for the day.
Quite powerful baseline intellect with a secondary proc effect trinket. Can also be farmed outside raid (The Dawnbreaker).

This trinket provides an on use damage effect every 90 seconds after the perform a simple task such as jump or collect an orb. Unfortunately at 90 seconds this does not line up well with any of our cooldowns.
This is an interesting passive trinket which will spawn waterspouts randomly, increased in damage by the number of targets hit.
Trinket that grants both main and secondary stats based on movement. Can also be  "used" to suspend your current buffs to allow more flexibility.
Trinket provides a baseline intellect but with a damage effect that increases per target hit. It's a fine direct damage option, though nothing to target or aim for generally.

Assassination Rogue.note: This is our BiS on-use trinket hands down. Mastery is a good stat, it's easy to use, lines up with all our cooldowns. What more could you want?
Strong on-use damage. If you can time it for the cooldown reset it's even better, but it's hard to play around and not necessary
A fan favorite and strong passive proc from Bfa makes a return. It's still great and should be sought out if you don't get your hands on  Ara-Kara Sacbrood first
A fan favorite and strong passive proc from Bfa makes a return. It's still great and should be sought out if you don't get your hands on  Ara-Kara Sacbrood first
This trinket is a nice passive proc trinket, but it is fairly RNG. The good news is that all secondary stats are good for Assassination, so there's no proc that "feels bad" in that regard
A surprisingly strong delve trinket, but the item level keeps it down compared to the higher listed trinkets
One of the best trinkets from the raid but loses to other options
This would be used in your passive slot typically. While min-maxing the buff is possible by standing still, it probably isn't worth it and can be mostly ignored

Similar to  Cache of Acquired Treasures, this trinket has three weapons it cycles through. It cycles between an AoE cone, a single target DoT, and a split damage frontal. It's a little annoying to play around and optimize, but pressing it on cooldown works fine, and it does decent damage especially in AoE situations

While this trinket sims as one of the best available from any content, the mini-games you have to do to get the buff makes this the worst trinket imaginable. They've made it easier since beta and the minigames are consistent positioning wise, but it remains completely unusable in any challenging environment. It's by far the worst trinket I have ever played with and only ranks this highly because the buff itself is still quite good.
One of the better Delve passive trinkets, the crit proc is tuned fairly well, but it does suffer from the lower item level
Does decent damage but you need to use  Sprint to get the most out of the effect. Very awkward trinket to use

Outlaw Rogue.note: A strong passive trinket that has added synergy with the  Void Reaper's Warp Blade weapon. You don't need this weapon for the trinket to be BIS. It's just an added bonus.

Half of the value of the trinket is due to helping us reach the Haste breakpoints required. A great option in general but depending on your Haste levels might be slightly worse than the other options.
A powerful on use trinket that can be especially powerful in Mythic plus where you can abuse the resets.
A strong general use trinket. One of the weapons does massive AoE damage. Make sure to use this trinket on cooldown, it's short cooldown will help you cycle to the AoE option quickly.
This trinket is generally weaker on single target than the other options, but the added cleave damage could be important for dungeons depending on your comp.

An incredibly strong trinket that is held down by the fact you can't increase to a higher reward track. It's a perfect trinket to chase down early in the tier, but it will fall off as you get Mythic gear. Make sure to use  Sprint every time it procs. Movement is not required; it just requires high movement speed.

A strong trinket that requires you to wiggle around a bit to maintain stacks. With Agility and Versatility being similar values this tier, this trinket is quite good. Focus on not going over 20 of either stack and the trinket is great. The on use also ignores double on use restriction.
It is just a damage on-use trinket. There's nothing special about it really.
A cute stat stick trinket that provides an extremely small buff to your party.
A passive trinket that requires you to apply it once every hour, similar to  Instant Poison. This resets on death so don't forget!!
It is an okay trinket that comes with a stat proc, also provides a buff to your group.

Subtlety Rogue.note: The best trinket for your 2nd trinket slot but a very contested trinket option.If you get this trinket, use it during  Symbols of Death as TricksterUse it during  Lingering Darkness when playing DeathstalkerIf combined with other on use trinkets like  Treacherous Transmitter, use  Mad Queen's Mandate second.

The best trinket for your 2nd trinket slot but a very contested trinket option.If you get this trinket, use it during  Symbols of Death as TricksterUse it during  Lingering Darkness when playing DeathstalkerIf combined with other on use trinkets like  Treacherous Transmitter, use  Mad Queen's Mandate second.

This trinket is one of the strong passive options. There is a set bonus on the item which increases the benefits if you use  Void Reaper's Warp Blade.Don't use the fist weapon under any circumstances, Subtlety Rogue's  Shadow Techniques proc heavily depends on Weapon speed, so using any non-dagger is not recommended.But the trinket is rly good without the weapon.

The trinket is only good if you are able to stand still, the on-use effect can be used to move once every 120 seconds. The use of this trinket in general is not recommended if you have other passive options.
The marks are target-bound. When using this trinket in Mythic+, make sure to keep attacking the same target if possible when using this option.
Best Delves trinket, has a high uptime.
Mastery is our best stat, good option for Mythic+ and okay alternative for your active trinket.
You can use  Sprint offensively for extra output.
Is technically not a DPS trinket option but seems to do decent damage with added benefits from the increased maximum health/shield.
Decent trinket from Delves. It is a strong option even if Haste is our weakest secondary stat.
Was initially one of the strongest options but got heavily nerfed, is not recommended to be used.

Elemental Shaman.note: Treacherous Transmitter is actually a pretty bad trinket. Even so, the sheer power of  Ascendance basically mandates that we want to have *some* on-use trinket, for which this is the second best choice. Do not set out to farm this. Do not use this if you have a  Spymaster's Web. It is still the best option if the damned thing just won't drop. Fulfilling the requests can be annoying in raids but should usually be very much doable. Just be aware to actually get the buff, i.e. finish the task before you press  Ascendance.

Ara-Kara Sacbrood supplements the on-use of the previous trinket very well. Haste is a very good stat, that we want a lot of and the passive damage from the proc isn't awful either. With this trinket being overbudgeted for its item-level, this ends up being the best secondary trinket, barely beating out other passive trinkets like the following one.

Unbound Changeling the second best passive stat trinket. Allowing you to choose the secondary provided by eating the respective buff foods, this trinket allows you to more easily fix your secondary stats during the gear-up stages. Usually the choice here is between mastery or haste, whichever sims highest for your specific gear. The "rare proc" that gives you a lesser amount of all secondaries is a DPS loss.

Treacherous Transmitter is actually a pretty bad trinket. Even so, the sheer power of  Ascendance basically mandates that we want to have *some* on-use trinket, for which this is the second best choice. Do not set out to farm this. Do not use this if you have a  Spymaster's Web. It is still the best option if the damned thing just won't drop. Fulfilling the requests can be annoying in raids but should usually be very much doable. Just be aware to actually get the buff, i.e. finish the task before you press  Ascendance.

Another pretty good secondary stat trinket. Competing for the spot of secondary trinket, giving random secondaries is sadly too bad to compete with trinkets that give you stats that are actually more desirable.
The first passive damage trinket on the list, this trinket does a surprisingly good job in Single Target, but can neither compete with the top performers nor scale well into AoE situations.

Similarly to the previous trinket,  Satchel of Misbegotten Minions performs surprisingly well in Single Target scenarios but gets outshone by the competition. Elemental Shaman scales exceptionally well with secondaries and, as such, are very bad at abusing flat damage items. The main stat on the item is nice but is not sufficient to get this trinket over A-rank.

Enhancement Shaman.note: Provides passive Agility and a large on-demand Mastery boost. Thanks to Patch 11.0.5 now also always aligns with  Ascendance, so is by far our best option. This is thanks to our Mastery being a force multiplier to begin, and our burst already being exceptional.

Provides passive Haste which at the start of the expansion we're absolutely desperate for and a very generous uptime rolling Agility proc, alongside a tiny amount of additional damage. Excellent all around for all situations, and very simple.

While this has a staggering 15 (+Haste) RPPM, the actual damage the proc deals isn't that special. The big value comes from the fact that for some inexplicable reason it procs Maelstrom Weapon, making it a heavy hitter for  Stormbringer builds in single target.

Passive Agility along with a 1.55 RPPM frequency secondary boost that, while random, is still extremely valuable this early in the expansion when we're desperate for any stat. Simple and effective in all situations.

Brings a lot of passive stats and the effect doesn't punish you too much in either the movement or stationary requirements, but still variable enough to be harmed by different fight styles and the need to micro-manage it. The on-use is best done when you have the egg balanced below 20 stacks due to the penalty after.

The only thing keeping this out of S tier is the lower item level from Delves. Passive Agility with on demand Haste every 2 minutes that, while also aligning with  Ascendance which is great. Very competitive option even with higher item level alternatives.

Brings a huge amount of passive stats, and the negative proc of stat reduction happens very infrequently making its high budget work it. Even at lower item levels the budget on this makes it keep up with higher item level alternatives, plus you can't really mess up stat sticks.

While this brings passive Haste and a huge amount of stats when used, it has the downside of being incredibly annoying to play around based on which minigame you get. The cooldown is also desynced with  Ascendance which hurts its value, but it does provide an on-use alternative if you can't get something better.

While we don't normally look for Crit on gear, since we're melee the chance you can double this buff up on an ally makes it extremely valuable for overall group damage. Less beneficial purely for us, but the net benefit makes it worth it.

Flat damage proc that, while it does get stronger if using the rare fist  Void Reaper's Warp Blade, starts out pretty weak because we simply don't stack Crit or Vers to amplify it alongside Haste this early on. Very weighted toward single target too which makes it even more specialized.

A solid Crit stat stick that's generally quite strong if you can maintain it. Unfortunately, in AoE this has a habit of proccing on things that are about to die, which massively reduces its value in Mythic+ situations. Still, good for raids and scenarios when you can maximize procs.

Restoration Shaman.note: A very strong stat-stick that can be used whenever you need additional healing. The only requirement is to regularly keep  Flame Shock active to generate stacks of the trinket.
A strong passive trinket that gives a lot of mainstat. Again, keeping  Flame Shock while healing will regularly proc this trinket.

This is a unique take on a passive stat-stick trinket. Standing still will build up stacks of  Deliberate Incubation which increases your mainstat over time, and moving will remove stacks of  Deliberate Incubation and instead grant stacks of  Reckless Incubation. This means you will never get zero value from this trinket, but it does award standing still as mainstat is generally better. Using the trinket will "suspend" the procs you have for a period of time, making it quite versatile.

This is a unique stat-stick that allows you to customize which secondary stat it procs by the food that you eat. This makes it very versatile, and it's also fairly easy to get since it comes from Mythic+.
This is your stereotypical stat-stick. Unfortunately this gives you a random secondary stat, so you can have streaks of "bad" secondary stat procs. Not terrible, not great.
This is another solid stat-stick where multiple stacks "overlap". This seems especially nice in a Mythic+ setting, as the damage procs also add in a small amount of damage.
While you do "lose" healing to charge up this trinket, the healing it does is decent and it also does an okay amount of damage for the group. This might be a nice trinket for Mythic+ especially.
A decent stat-stick, and one of the the only really notable trinkets from Delves.
An okay trinket that will passively add some healing. There are better options.
Another decent trinket from Delves. This is beaten out by higher item level trinkets, but fine early in the season if you get your hands on a high item level one.

Affliction Warlock.note: Strong trinket with a main stat stacking effect and an on-use that accrues value passively.
Unique trinket that grants Intellect once eggs are spawned. When they hatch, damage is also dealt. The hatching of eggs takes a bit of time however to occur.
Mad Queen's Mandate is essentially our "Best" raw single target damage option, but has very little AOE value.

Unbound Changeling can proc a random secondary stat, but also has a chance to "change" into a version that grants ALL secondary stats, this chance can occur the first time you eat food in-game for the day.
Trinket provides baseline Intellect and a damage proc. Orbs can also be soaked to increase your Mastery, but requires movement.
